Award.AwardTitle: Workshop to Explore US/Korean Collaboration in Human-Friendly Co-Robotic Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports a workshop on U.S. and South Korean collaboration in the area of robotics, specifically humanoid robots that collaborate with people. International collaboration is important for keeping U.S. researchers abreast of the latest technological developments around the world, which have impact on our quality of life, quality of work, and quality of education. The workshop will be held in conjunction with the International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS), in Vancouver, Canada, September 2017. The focus of the workshop is to keep abreast of latest developments in robotics research, communicate the benefits of the U.S. environment supporting leading edge innovation, and begin a ?match-making? process to connect U.S. and South Korean robotics researchers. The goal is to develop a sustainable model for international collaboration, where the benefits exceed the added administrative burdens typical of such collaborations. Innovative approaches both during and after the workshop will be employed in order to develop and nurture nascent research collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this workshop series was to encourage international collaboration in robotics, which is an area of U.S. and Korean national need. We did this by bringing together researchers interested in the field from both sides of the Pacific Ocean to search for points of common interest. We specifically focused on South Korea because of the success of the Korean entry into the DARPA Robotics Challenge (humanoid and disaster robotics) and the common interest in robotic handling of nuclear waste.

We organized two workshops at one of the largest international academic robotics conferences in the world, in conjunction with South Korean colleagues and additonal funding from South Korea. (Koreas travel was funded by teh Koreans and US travel was funded by the Americans.) The RSJ/IEEE International Robots and Systems conference (IROS) brings together thousands of robotic scientists from all over the world. We held the initial workshop in 2017 in Vancouver and then followed up that with a second workshop in 2019 in Macao, China. In total, we brought together 55 robotics scientists to discuss their work and possibilities for collaboration. This included 32 US scientists and 23 Korean scientists over the two years.

Although no specific new joint projects were initiated, the 55 scientists got to meet with each other and learn more about one anothers research activities and stronger relationships were built. Many participants felt they had better insights for future collaboration.

There has also been an ongoing dialog between senior US and Korean scientists. An international panel of government scientific agencies has been organized for many years at the two major international robotics conferences and involvement of the senior scientists from this workshop series has increased. 

A few specific robotics-related spin-off activities have emerged that were partially driven or facilitated by this workshop. One of those was the creation of a robotics roadmap for the US Dept. of Energy. As part of this effort, a number of countries were visited by a team of US robotics experts to exchange information on the remote handling of high-consequence materials to promote better nuclear safety. South Korea was included in this exchange and several of the senior scientists from this workshop participated. Also, a delegation of US robotics experts participated in a Korean conference in Korea on remote handling of nuclear materials in 2017 and exchanged information of nuclear power plant safety.
